title: Statistical blending of weather data sets
abstract: In an approach, a method for fusing point data with areal averages is performed by a computing system. The fusion procedure is coherent, in the sense that the computing system takes into account what the areal averages represent with respect to the point data. The overarching goal is to fit a model that takes into account the information derived from both data sets. The areal averages provide an estimate for what the integral of a model representing the behavior of the environmental variable should be over a particular district and the point values indicate the estimated value at particular locations. Thus, the integral of the fitted model over a district of the grid should approximate the value provided by the areal averages while also approximating the value provided by the point data for locations which are provided by the point data.
claims:
1. A method comprising:
receiving set of observations and set of areal average observations for a field;
defining a state-space model that maps the set observations and the set of areal average observations onto a set of latent Gaussian processes and describes how the set of latent Gaussian processes evolves over time;
setting an initial mean and an initial variance for each Gaussian process of the set of latent Gaussian processes in the state-space model based on observations of the set of observations that relate to an initial time step of a set of time steps;
starting with the initial time step of the set of time steps and ending at a final time step of the set of time steps, for each Gaussian process of the set of latent Gaussian processes, repeating a process of fitting the state-space model to the set of observations by:
generating a predicted mean and a predicted variance for a next time step of the Gaussian process based on the state-space model, a mean of the Gaussian process at a current time step of the set of time steps, and a variance of the Gaussian process at the current time step; and
updating the predicted mean and the predicted variance based on one or more observations of the set of observations that relate to the next time step, resulting in a mean and a variance of the Gaussian process for the next time step and updating, using the mean and the variance of the Gaussian process, the state-space model to improve accuracy of a weather forecast for the area under observation.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the set of observations includes one or more point-observations, each point observation of the one or more point-observations specifies a value and a variance of an environmental variable at a particular location of an area under observation and a time step of a set of time steps, and each areal average observation of the set of areal average observations specifies a value and a variance for a district of a grid superimposed over the area under observation and a time step of the set of time steps;
wherein updating the predicted mean and the predicted variance is performed according to a Bayes rule.
3. The method of claim 2, wherein the state-space model specifies that the set of latent Gaussian processes is updated at each time step by applying a vector of spatially correlated, but temporally independent, Gaussian shocks.
4. The method of claim 3, further comprising: receiving a location and a time step for which to predict a value and a variance of the environmental variable; and
estimating the value and the variance of the environmental variable based on a fitted state-space model.
5. The method of claim 4, wherein the estimating of the value and the variance of the environmental variable is performed by: constructing an auxiliary vector which relates the location to Gaussian processes of the fitted state-space model for the time step; and
estimating the value and the variance of the environmental variable based on the auxiliary vector, the Gaussian processes, and a measurement error.
6. The method of claim 5, wherein the one or more point-observations represent measurements taken from one or more weather stations and the set of areal average observations represents measurements taken from one or more of: one or more reanalysis products or one or more satellite images.
7. The method of claim 6, wherein the fitted state-space model maps the one or more point-observations and the set of areal average observations to the set of latent Gaussian processes using a sparse matrix.
8. The method of claim 7, wherein each entry of the sparse matrix is constructed by evaluating a kernel function that only takes non-zero values within a predefined spatial range.
9. The method of claim 8, wherein the sparse matrix is multiplied by a plurality of temporal harmonics to capture a seasonal variability.
10. The method of claim 9, further comprising: in response to determining that a point observation for a particular time step is missing from the one or more point-observations, using a value and a variance of a corresponding areal average observation of the set of areal average observations instead when fitting the fitted state-space model.
11. The method of claim 10, wherein the fitted state-space model maps the one or more point-observations and the set of areal average observations onto the set of latent Gaussian processes using compactly supported kernels configured to hold sparse covariance matrices.
12. The method of claim 11, wherein the fitted state-space model takes into consideration one or more of: a measurement error of the set of observations or an estimation error of the set of observations.
13. The method of claim 12, wherein the fitting of the fitted state-space model applies the Bayes rule to update spatial covariance matrices such that the spatial covariance matrices remain sparse during a forward fitting stage and a backward smoothing stage.
14. The method of claim 13, wherein the fitted state-space model accounts for a multitude of seasonal signals, as well as a spatial correlation, and allows for a magnitude of a multitude of seasonal signals and the spatial correlation to vary across a space.
